facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2517 of 1969 from Judgment and Order dated 31st March, 1969 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in City Civil Court Appeal No. 71 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2517 of 1969. From the Judgment and Order dated 31st March, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad, in Ci

facts.text: Plaintiff-Respondent sued Defendant-Appellant Devender Singh (First Defendant) for specific performance of contract to sell house facing Secunderabad Junction Railway Station for Rs. 60,000/- concluded on 9-10-1962 at New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The Plaintiff-Respondent had sued Defendant-Appellant Devender Singh  hereinafter referred to as the First Defendant  for specific performance of a companytract to sell a house facing the Secunderabad Junction Railway Station in Hyderabad for a sum of Rs. 60,000/- companycluded on 9-10-1962 at New Delhi where the first Defendant resides.

facts.text: Previous agreement on 27-9-1962 between Plaintiff and First Defendant through agent Laxmanaswamy (D.W. 2) with help of Sambamurthy (D.W. 3) for sale of property for Rs. 55,000/- embodied in document Ex. B. 15.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was a previous agreement on 27-9-1962  hereinafter referred to as the first agreement  between the Plaintiff, who resides at Hyderabad, and the first Defendant, through an agent, Laxmanaswamy, D.W. 2, with the help of Sambamurthy, D.W. 3, a nephew of Laxmanaswamy and an Income-tax practitioner residing at Secunderabad, for the sale of this very property for Rs. 55,0001- the terms of which were embodied in a document Ex. B. 15.

facts.text: Plaintiff drew cheque for Rs. 10,000/- in favour of First Defendant and handed it to his agent under first agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The First Defendant denies the binding character of the first agreement of 27-9-1962 under which a cheque for Rs. 10,000/- was drawn up by the Plaintiff in favour of the first Defen- dant and handed over to his agent by the Plaintiff.

facts.text: Cheque for Rs. 10,000/- was cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: The exact reason for a cancellation of this cheque for Rs. 10,000/- in favour of the 1st Defendant is number clear,

facts.text: According to Sambamurthy (D.W. 3), reason for cancellation was demand for Rs. 20,000/- earnest money to which plaintiff consented.

anchor.surface_text: but, according to Sambamurthy, D.W. 3, the reason was that, actually, Rs. 20,000/- was being demanded on behalf of the first Defendant as earnest money to which the plaintiff had companysented so that a new cheque was, for some unknown reas on, to be issued and number another cheque for Rs. 10,000/.

facts.text: Plaintiff became aware of want of written authority of Laxmanaswamy or Sambamurthy to conclude contract on behalf of First Defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of Sainbamurthy also show that the Plaintiff had become aware of want of written authority on the part of either Laxmanaswamy or Sambamurthy to companyclude the companytract on behalf of the 1st Defendant so that be must have felt uncertain about the effect of the first agreement.

facts.text: First Defendant denies binding character of first agreement of 27-9-1962.

anchor.surface_text: The First Defendant denies the binding character of the first agreement of 27-9-1962 under which a cheque for Rs. 10,000/- was drawn up by the Plaintiff in favour of the first Defen- dant and handed over to his agent by the Plaintiff.

facts.text: Under agreement of 9-10-1962, Rs. 20,000/- paid as earnest money: Rs. 10,000/- cash and Rs. 10,000/- by cheque dated 9-10-1962.

anchor.surface_text: by offering Rs. 60,000, - as the price of the property, out of which Rs. 20,000/- was paid is earnest money  Rs. 10,000, - in cash and Rs. 10,0100/- by a cheque dated 9-10-1962  and the balance at the time of registration,

facts.text: First Defendant executed agreement of 9-10-1962 (Ex. A1).

anchor.surface_text: to induce the first Defendant himself to companyclude and execute the fresh agreement of 9-10-1962. The deed of agreement of 9-10-1962 Ex. Al was number executed in a hurry by the first Defendant.

facts.text: Trial Court and High Court found First Defendant fully aware and entered agreement of 9-10-1962 with open eyes, no pressure, misrepresentation or fraud.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court as well as the High Court had found that the first Defendant was fully aware of all the facts and had entered into the agreement of 9th October, 1962, with open eyes because it was the most advantageous transaction open to the first Defendant at that time and number as a result of any pressure or misrepresentation or fraud practised upon the first Defendant,

facts.text: First Defendant is middle aged hard headed astute businessman, Director of Blackwood Hodge Pvt. Ltd., connected with other business concerns.

anchor.surface_text: a middle aged hard headed and astute businessman who deposed that he was a Director of Blackwood Hodge  Pvt.  Ltd., and was companynected with a number of other business companycerns.

facts.text: First Defendant stated he entered agreement of 9-10-1962 because a bird in hand worth two in bush.

anchor.surface_text: He had himself stated in his evidence in Court that he entered into the agreement of 9-10-1962 because he companysidered that a bird in hand was worth two in the bush and had thus given out the real reason for the agreement of 9-10-1962.

facts.text: First Defendant sold property under deed dated 19-10-1962 (Ex. B.22) for Rs. 70,000/- to Gulam Hussain Jowkar (2nd Def), Rajab (3rd), Safar Jowkar (4th), Hussain Jowkar (5th), Wali Husstin Nasab (6th), partners in Alpha Hotel (7th Def).

anchor.surface_text: The first Defendant bad, however, ignoring the companytract of 9-10-1962, actually sold the property under a deed dated 19- 10-1962 Ex. B. 22 for a sum of Rs. 70,000- - received from Gulam Hussain Jowkar  2nd Defendant , Rajab  3rd Defendant , Safar Jowkar  4th Defendant , Hussain Jowkar  5th Defendant , Wali Husstin Nasab  6th Defendant , all partners in the firm carrying on the business of running Alpha Hotel  7th Defendant , situated in front of the Railway Station at Secunderabad

facts.text: First Defendant pleaded contract of 9-10-1962 result of misrepresentation and fraud.

anchor.surface_text: The first Defendant had, in answer to the suit of the PlaintiffResponsent, pleased that the companytract of 9-10- 1.962 was the result of mis-representation and fraud.

facts.text: Trial Court and High Court found plea of fraud and misrepresentation baseless.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Trial Court and the High Court had found the plea of fraud and mis-representation taken by the first Defendant to be baseless.

facts.text: Trial Court denied specific performance, awarded return of Rs.20,000 earnest, Rs.20,000 liquidated damages, Rs.2,300 additional damages, interest at 6% p.a., costs.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the Trial Court thought that the plaintiff was number entitled to specific performance of the agreement of 9-10-1962, but awarded a decree for the return of Rs. 20,000/- to the plaintiff, which he had paid to the first Defendant as earliest money, and for damages of Rs. 20,000/- , which had been stipulated for by way of liquidated damages or penalty in the agreement of 9-10-1962 and for additional damages to the extent of Rs. 2,300/. Interest at 6 per annum and the companyts of the suit were also. awarded to the Plaintiff by the Trial Court.

facts.text: High Court found no unfair advantage to plaintiff, decreed specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had rightly found, after a thorough re- exammation of. evidence in the case, that it was impossible to hold that the plaintiff had obtained any unfair advantage over the first Defendant in companycluding the agreement of 9-10-1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, dismiss this appeal with companyts.

arguments.claim: First defendant entered agreement with open eyes, fully aware, no pressure

holdings.text: The mere existence of a clause in a contract providing for liquidated damages or a penalty for a breach is not sufficient to rebut the presumption raised by the explanation to Section 12 of the Specific Relief Act 1877

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the parties themselves have provided a sum to be paid by the party breaking the contract does not, by itself, remove the strong presumption contemplated by the use of the words unless and until the contrary is proved. The sufficiency or insufficiency of any evidence to remove such a presumption is a matter of evidence. The fact that the parties themselves specified a sum of money to be paid in the event of its breach is, no doubt, a piece of evidence to be considered in deciding whether the presumption has been repelled or not. But, in our opinion, it is nothing more than a piece of evidence. It is not conclusive or decisive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 20 of the old Act allows specific performance despite named sum for breach; such clause is evidence but not conclusive to rebut presumption; supported by Section 23 of 1963 Act and Fry's principles distinguishing securing performance from alternative payment

holdings.text: If the presumption in the Explanation to Section 12 is rebutted, the bar in Section 21 does not ipso facto become operative

anchor.surface_text: The second assumption underlying the contentions on behalf of the Defendants-appellants is that, once the presumption, contained in explanation to Section 12 of the old Act, is removed, the, bar contained in Section 21 of the old Act, against the specific enforcement of a contract for which compensation in money is an adequate relief, automatically operates, over-looks that the condition for the imposition of the bar is actual proof that compensation in money is adequate on the facts and circumstances of a particular case before the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires actual proof of adequacy of monetary compensation even after presumption rebutted; presumption only shifts burden, plaintiff can still prove inadequacy

holdings.text: Specific performance of a contract may be enforced though a sum be named in it as the amount to be paid in case of its breach if the contract is otherwise proper to be specifically enforced and the party in default is willing to pay the same

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the 1st assumption is provided by Section 20 of the old Act. It reads A contract, otherwise proper to be specifically forced, may be thus enforced, though a sum be named in it as the amount to be paid, in case of its breach, and the party in default is willing to pay the same. If the Legislative intent was that the mere proof that a sum is specified as liquidated damages or penalty for a breach should be enough to prove that a contract for the transfer of immovable property could be adequately compensated by the specified damages or penalty Section 20 of the old Act will certainly become meaningless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Section 20 SRA 1877; reenacted in Section 23 SRA 1963; distinguishes contracts securing performance via penalty/damages from those offering payment as alternative

holdings.text: The presumption contained in the explanation to Section 12 of the old Act was not rebutted in this case

anchor.surface_text: The result in that we think that the presumption contained in the explanation to Section 12 of the old Act was not rebutted here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence led to prove adequacy of monetary compensation; property has special value due to location; no standard for loss of prospective gains; clause alone insufficient

holdings.text: The jurisdiction to decree specific performance is discretionary but must be exercised on sound judicial principles capable of correction by a court of appeal; High Court rightly interfered with Trial Court's erroneous exercise of discretion

anchor.surface_text: A reference to Section 22 of the old Act,  the corresponding provision is Section 20 of the Act of  1963 , would show that the jurisdiction of the Court to decree specific relief is discretionary and must be exercised on sound and reasonable grounds guided by judicial principles and capable of correction by a Court of appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial Court erred on untenable ground of unfair advantage to plaintiff, which was factually incorrect; discretion not arbitrary but judicial and reviewable

holdings.text: The High Court rightly decreed specific performance of the contract dated 9-10-1962

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had rightly decreed the suit for specific performance of the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract valid, no fraud or misrepresentation; presumption not rebutted; no adequate monetary relief; discretion correctly exercised by High Court

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, dismiss this appeal with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with costs upholding High Court decree for specific performance

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the parties themselves have provided a sum to be paid by the party breaking the contract does not, by itself, remove the strong presumption contemplated by the use of the words unless and until the contrary is proved. The sufficiency or insufficiency of any evidence to remove such a presumption is a matter of evidence. The fact that the parties themselves specified a sum of money to be paid in the event of its breach is, no doubt, a piece of evidence to be considered in deciding whether the presumption has been repelled or not. But, in our opinion, it is nothing more than a piece of evidence. It is not conclusive or decisive.
We, therefore, dismiss this appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The second assumption underlying the contentions on behalf of the Defendants-appellants is that, once the presumption, contained in explanation to Section 12 of the old Act, is removed, the, bar contained in Section 21 of the old Act, against the specific enforcement of a contract for which compensation in money is an adequate relief, automatically operates, over-looks that the condition for the imposition of the bar is actual proof that compensation in money is adequate on the facts and circumstances of a particular case before the Court.
We, therefore, dismiss this appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the 1st assumption is provided by Section 20 of the old Act. It reads A contract, otherwise proper to be specifically forced, may be thus enforced, though a sum be named in it as the amount to be paid, in case of its breach, and the party in default is willing to pay the same. If the Legislative intent was that the mere proof that a sum is specified as liquidated damages or penalty for a breach should be enough to prove that a contract for the transfer of immovable property could be adequately compensated by the specified damages or penalty Section 20 of the old Act will certainly become meaningless.
We, therefore, dismiss this appeal with costs.
